title: Course Launch: Money Rules Baseline
description: Your first paycheck is coming — do you actually know what happens to your money before it hits your bank account? This module builds the vocabulary and number sense you need to read a pay stub without guessing, understand where your money goes before you spend it, and start making real financial decisions instead of winging it.
goals: Define and calculate gross pay, net pay, and common paycheck deductions for both hourly and salaried workers
Read a real pay stub and identify every line item — gross pay, federal and state taxes, Social Security, Medicare, and voluntary deductions
Explain the difference between checking and savings accounts, and between debit and credit cards, using specific financial examples
Categorize personal expenses as wants or needs and calculate what percentage of a real budget goes to each
Make informed financial decisions by comparing job offers, bank accounts, and spending plans using actual dollar amounts
instructionalStrategy: Start every concept with a realistic scenario — actual paychecks, actual tax rates, actual bank balances. Abstract 'what-if' problems don't build financial intuition.
Use round-ish but not perfectly round numbers. Real paychecks are $1,317.47, not $1,000. Students need to get comfortable with messy arithmetic.
Push students past calculation into decision-making: 'Which job pays more?' is better than 'What is the gross pay?' The math should serve a purpose.
Pay stub literacy is a life skill most adults were never taught. Treat it like learning to read — systematic, patient, but non-negotiable.
Wants vs needs is NOT a moral judgment. Frame it as a budgeting tool: needs get funded first, wants get funded with what's left. No shame, just math.

scaffold.title: Income Vocabulary: Gross Pay, Net Pay, and Where Your Money Goes
scaffold.content:
Before you can manage money, you need to speak its language. When you get a job, you'll hear terms like gross pay, net pay, withholdings, and deductions thrown around — and if you don't know what they mean, you'll be confused every time you look at your paycheck.

Here's the reality: if your job pays $16 an hour for 40 hours, you might expect $640 in your bank account. But you'll actually see something closer to $490. Where did the other $150 go? Taxes and deductions — and understanding those is the first step to taking control of your money.
keyPoints: Gross pay = total earnings BEFORE anything is taken out. For hourly workers: hours worked × hourly rate. For salaried workers: annual salary ÷ number of pay periods.
Net pay (take-home pay) = gross pay MINUS all taxes and deductions. This is what actually lands in your bank account.
Hourly vs salaried: Hourly workers get paid per hour and usually earn overtime (1.5× rate) after 40 hours/week. Salaried workers receive a fixed annual amount regardless of hours.
Withholdings: amounts your employer sends to the government for you — federal income tax, state income tax, Social Security (6.2%), and Medicare (1.45%).
Deductions: additional amounts subtracted from your paycheck — health insurance premiums, retirement contributions (401k), union dues, dental/vision insurance.
Pay periods: Biweekly = every 2 weeks (26 paychecks/year). Semi-monthly = twice a month on fixed dates (24 paychecks/year). Monthly = once a month (12 paychecks/year).

examples.problem: Marcus earns $16.50 per hour and works 40 hours per week. Calculate his weekly gross pay and his biweekly gross pay.
examples.solution:
Weekly gross pay = hours × rate = 40 × $16.50 = $660.00.
Biweekly (every two weeks) = $660.00 × 2 = $1,320.00.

Note: Marcus hasn't seen a dime yet — this is BEFORE taxes and deductions. His take-home pay will be significantly less.

examples.problem: Priya accepts a job with an annual salary of $41,600. What is her gross pay per biweekly paycheck? Per month?
examples.solution:
Biweekly: There are 26 biweekly pay periods per year.
$41,600 ÷ 26 = $1,600.00 per paycheck.

Monthly: $41,600 ÷ 12 = $3,466.67 per month.

Key insight: Biweekly and semi-monthly are NOT the same thing. Biweekly = every 2 weeks (26 times/year). Semi-monthly = twice a month on fixed dates (24 times/year). The per-paycheck amount differs.

examples.problem: Deshawn earns $14.00/hour and worked 46 hours this week. His overtime rate is 1.5× for any hours over 40. What is his gross pay for the week?
examples.solution:
Regular pay: 40 hours × $14.00 = $560.00.
Overtime rate: $14.00 × 1.5 = $21.00/hour.
Overtime pay: 6 hours × $21.00 = $126.00.
Total gross pay: $560.00 + $126.00 = $686.00.

The 6 overtime hours earned Deshawn an extra $42.00 compared to what he'd make at his regular rate ($126 at overtime vs $84 at regular). Overtime adds up fast.

problems.question: Aisha earns $19.25 per hour and works 35 hours this week. What is her gross pay for the week?
hints: Gross pay for hourly workers = hours worked × hourly rate.
Multiply: 35 × $19.25. Break it up if that helps: 35 × $19 = $665, and 35 × $0.25 = $8.75. Then add.

problems.question: Two job offers: Job A pays $17.00/hr for a guaranteed 40 hours per week. Job B offers an annual salary of $36,400. Which job has a higher gross pay per year, and by how much?
hints: For Job A, calculate annual gross: hourly rate × 40 hours × 52 weeks.
For Job B, the annual salary is already stated: $36,400.
Compare the two annual totals to find the difference.
problems.answer: Job A: $17.00 × 40 × 52 = $35,360/year. Job B: $36,400/year. Job B pays $1,040 more per year.

problems.question: Carlos earns $15.50/hr and worked 44 hours this week. He receives 1.5× pay for overtime hours (anything over 40). Calculate his gross pay for the week.
hints: Split the hours: 40 regular + 4 overtime.
Overtime rate = $15.50 × 1.5 = $23.25 per hour.
Regular pay: 40 × $15.50 = $620.00. Overtime pay: 4 × $23.25 = $93.00. Add them together.

problems.question: Keyla earns an annual salary of $38,480. Her coworker Dante earns $18.50 per hour and works exactly 40 hours every week, 52 weeks a year. Who earns more gross pay per year, and by how much?
problems.answer: Keyla: $38,480/year. Dante: $18.50 × 40 × 52 = $38,480/year. They earn exactly the same gross pay per year.

problems.question: Jordan is deciding between two job offers. Job 1: $19.50/hr, 40 hrs/week, with average overtime of 5 extra hours per week at 1.5× rate. Job 2: $48,000 annual salary, no overtime pay. Based on annual gross pay, which pays more? What risk should Jordan consider before choosing?
problems.answer: Job 1 regular: $19.50 × 40 × 52 = $40,560. Overtime: $29.25 × 5 × 52 = $7,605. Total = $48,165. Job 2: $48,000. Job 1 pays $165 more per year WITH overtime — but overtime is not guaranteed. If overtime hours drop, Job 1 falls to $40,560. Job 2's guaranteed $48,000 is the safer choice.

scaffold.title: Reading a Pay Stub: Your Paycheck's Receipt
scaffold.content:
A pay stub is the most important financial document you'll see on a regular basis — and most people never learn how to read one. It's the detailed breakdown that comes with every paycheck, showing exactly where every dollar of your gross pay went. Learning to read it is like learning to read a nutrition label, except it's for your money.

Every pay stub has the same basic structure: gross pay at the top, a list of everything that gets subtracted (taxes and deductions), and your net pay at the bottom. The difference between those two numbers can be shocking the first time you see it.
keyPoints: Gross pay appears at the top — your total earnings for the pay period before anything is taken out.
Federal income tax: withheld based on your W-4 form and tax bracket. Common effective rates for entry-level workers: 10-12% of gross.
State income tax: varies by state from 0% (Texas, Florida, Nevada) up to 13%+ (California). Most states fall in the 3-6% range.
Social Security (FICA): exactly 6.2% of your gross pay — everyone pays the same rate, no exceptions.
Medicare: exactly 1.45% of your gross pay — also the same for everyone.
Voluntary deductions appear below taxes: health insurance premiums, 401(k) retirement contributions, dental, vision, life insurance, union dues.
Net pay is the bottom line = Gross pay minus ALL withholdings and deductions. This is what gets deposited into your bank account.

examples.problem:
Read this pay stub and calculate the net pay.

Employee: Sarah Chen | Pay Period: Biweekly
Gross Pay: $1,850.00
--- Taxes ---
Federal Income Tax: $222.00
State Income Tax: $74.00
Social Security (6.2%): $114.70
Medicare (1.45%): $26.83
--- Deductions ---
Health Insurance: $95.00
Net Pay: ???
examples.solution:
Add all withholdings and deductions:
$222.00 + $74.00 + $114.70 + $26.83 + $95.00 = $532.53.

Net pay = $1,850.00 - $532.53 = $1,317.47.

Sarah earned $1,850 but takes home $1,317.47. That's 71.2% of her gross pay. Nearly 29 cents of every dollar went to taxes and insurance before she could spend anything.

examples.problem: Tyrese's pay stub is missing the gross pay line. His deductions are: Federal tax $192.00, State tax $64.00, Social Security $99.20, Medicare $23.20, union dues $15.00. His net pay (deposited to his bank) was $1,206.60. What was his gross pay?
examples.solution:
Work backwards: Gross = Net + all deductions.
Total deductions: $192.00 + $64.00 + $99.20 + $23.20 + $15.00 = $393.40.
Gross pay = $1,206.60 + $393.40 = $1,600.00.

Verification: Social Security should be 6.2% of gross. $1,600.00 × 0.062 = $99.20. Medicare: $1,600.00 × 0.0145 = $23.20. Both match — the numbers check out.

examples.problem: Compare these two pay stubs. Worker A: Gross $1,400.00, total deductions $336.00. Worker B: Gross $2,200.00, total deductions $561.00. Who keeps a higher percentage of their gross pay?
examples.solution:
Worker A: Net = $1,400.00 - $336.00 = $1,064.00. Take-home percentage: $1,064 / $1,400 = 76.0%.
Worker B: Net = $2,200.00 - $561.00 = $1,639.00. Take-home percentage: $1,639 / $2,200 = 74.5%.

Worker A keeps 76.0% vs Worker B's 74.5%. Even though Worker B takes home more dollars ($1,639 vs $1,064), Worker A keeps a higher percentage. Higher income often means a higher tax bracket and more deductions.

problems.question: Calculate the net pay from this biweekly pay stub. Gross Pay: $2,080.00. Federal Tax: $249.60. State Tax: $83.20. Social Security: $128.96. Medicare: $30.16. Health Insurance: $110.00.
hints: Total deductions = $601.92. Now subtract from gross pay.

problems.question: Nina's biweekly gross pay is $1,560.00. Her deductions: federal tax $187.20, state tax $62.40, Social Security $96.72, Medicare $22.62, dental insurance $28.50. What is her net pay, and what percentage of her gross does she actually take home? Round to the nearest percent.
hints: Take-home percentage = (Net ÷ Gross) × 100 = ($1,162.56 ÷ $1,560.00) × 100.

problems.question: A pay stub shows: Gross Pay $1,720.00. Federal Tax $206.40. State Tax: MISSING. Social Security $106.64. Medicare $24.94. 401(k) Contribution $86.00. Net Pay $1,193.02. Find the missing state tax amount.
hints: All deductions plus net pay must equal gross pay.

problems.question: Read this weekly pay stub and answer both parts. Gross Pay: $742.50. Federal Income Tax: $89.10. State Income Tax: $29.70. Social Security: $46.04. Medicare: $10.77. No other deductions. (a) What is the net pay? (b) If this worker saves 10% of their net pay each week, how much goes to savings?

DeShawn's biweekly pay stub shows: Gross pay $2,240.00, federal tax $268.80, state tax $89.60, Social Security $138.88, Medicare $32.48, health insurance $135.00, 401(k) contribution $112.00. His monthly rent is $950. Assuming two paychecks per month, can he afford rent and still have at least $1,000 left over for other expenses? Show your work.
problems.answer: Total deductions: $776.76. Net per paycheck: $2,240.00 - $776.76 = $1,463.24. Monthly net (2 paychecks): $2,926.48. After rent ($950): $2,926.48 - $950 = $1,976.48. Yes — he has $1,976.48 left, well above the $1,000 threshold.

scaffold.title: Banking Basics: Where Your Money Lives
scaffold.content:
Once your net pay hits your bank account, you need to understand the tools you're working with. A bank account isn't just a place to stash cash — the type of account and the type of card you use directly affects how much money you keep, how much you spend, and whether you accidentally borrow money without realizing it.

The two biggest mistakes new earners make: keeping all their money in checking (missing out on interest) and treating a credit card like free money (then paying 22% interest on a burrito). Both are avoidable if you understand the basics.
keyPoints: Checking account: designed for everyday spending — debit card purchases, bill payments, direct deposit. Earns little to no interest. The goal is easy access.
Savings account: designed for money you don't need right now. Earns interest (typically 3-5% APY in high-yield accounts). May limit monthly withdrawals.
Debit card: swipe it and the money comes directly from your checking account immediately. You can only spend what you have.
Credit card: swipe it and you're BORROWING money from the card company. You must pay it back. If you don't pay the full balance by the due date, you're charged interest (typically 18-25% APR).
Overdraft: if your checking balance goes below $0, the bank charges an overdraft fee — typically $25-$35 per transaction. One mistake can cascade into multiple fees.
Interest works in two directions: savings accounts pay YOU interest (the bank pays you for holding your money). Credit cards charge YOU interest (you pay the bank for borrowing their money).

examples.problem:
Track this checking account balance through the week.
Starting balance: $1,247.50
Monday: Direct deposit +$1,320.00
Tuesday: Rent payment -$875.00
Wednesday: Grocery purchase -$62.38
Friday: Electric bill -$94.15
What is the ending balance?
examples.solution:
Starting: $1,247.50
After deposit: $1,247.50 + $1,320.00 = $2,567.50
After rent: $2,567.50 - $875.00 = $1,692.50
After groceries: $1,692.50 - $62.38 = $1,630.12
After electric: $1,630.12 - $94.15 = $1,535.97

Ending balance: $1,535.97. Key habit: always know your balance BEFORE making a purchase, not after.

examples.problem: Mia puts $2,000 into a savings account earning 4.5% APY (annual percentage yield). If interest is calculated at the end of the year, how much interest does she earn? What is her new balance?
examples.solution:
Interest = Principal × Rate = $2,000.00 × 0.045 = $90.00.
New balance: $2,000.00 + $90.00 = $2,090.00.

Mia earned $90 for doing literally nothing — just leaving money in the account. Compare this to a checking account earning 0%: same money, $90 difference. This is why savings accounts exist.

examples.problem: Jayden charges $800 on a credit card with a 22% APR. He only makes the minimum payment of $25 per month. After one month, how much interest is charged, and what is his new balance?
examples.solution:
Monthly interest rate = 22% ÷ 12 = 1.833%.
Interest for month 1: $800.00 × 0.01833 = $14.67.
After $25 minimum payment:
New balance = $800.00 + $14.67 - $25.00 = $789.67.

Jayden paid $25 but only reduced his actual debt by $10.33. The other $14.67 went straight to the credit card company as interest. At minimum payments, this $800 would take over 40 months to pay off and cost over $200 in interest on top of the original $800.

problems.question: Track this checking account. Starting balance: $834.20. Transactions: Deposit $675.00, ATM withdrawal $60.00, online bill pay $125.50, debit card purchase $43.87. What is the final balance?
hints: Add deposits to the balance and subtract all withdrawals and purchases.
After deposit: $834.20 + $675.00 = $1,509.20. Now subtract each outgoing transaction one at a time.

problems.question: Layla has $5,000 to deposit into savings. Bank A offers 3.8% APY. Bank B offers 4.25% APY. How much more interest would she earn at Bank B after one year?
hints: Calculate interest at each bank: Interest = Principal × Rate.
Subtract to find the difference.

problems.question: Omar charges $1,200 on a credit card with an 18% APR. He pays $100 per month. How much interest is charged the first month, and how much of his $100 payment actually goes toward reducing the balance? What is his new balance?
hints: Monthly interest rate = APR ÷ 12 = 18% ÷ 12 = 1.5%.
First month interest: $1,200 × 0.015 = $18.00.
Of his $100 payment, $18 goes to interest and the rest reduces the balance: $100 - $18 = $82 toward principal. New balance = $1,200 - $82 = $1,118.
problems.answer: $18.00 in interest. $82.00 of the $100 payment reduces the balance. New balance: $1,118.00.

problems.question: Aaliyah's checking account has $2,150.00. She writes a rent check for $1,100.00, buys gas for $47.25, receives a direct deposit of $1,465.00, and pays her phone bill of $89.99. Her bank charges a $35.00 overdraft fee if the balance drops below $0 at any point during the sequence. Process each transaction in order — does she ever overdraft? What is her final balance?

Tomas has $3,000 in a savings account earning 4.0% APY. He also has $3,000 in credit card debt at 24% APR. How much interest does his savings earn in one year? How much interest does his credit card charge in just the first month? Should he use his savings to pay off the credit card debt? Use the numbers to explain your decision.
problems.answer: Savings earns: $3,000 × 0.04 = $120.00 per year. Credit card charges: $3,000 × 0.24 ÷ 12 = $60.00 in the FIRST MONTH alone. The credit card costs $60/month while savings earns only $10/month ($120/12). He should absolutely use his savings to pay off the card — the 24% he's paying crushes the 4% he's earning. He'd save hundreds of dollars in interest over the year.

scaffold.title: Wants vs Needs: The Budget Categories That Actually Matter
scaffold.content:
Every dollar you spend falls into one of two categories: something you NEED or something you WANT. This isn't about judging your choices — it's about knowing which expenses you can cut when money gets tight and which ones you're stuck with no matter what.

If your car breaks down and you need $1,200 for repairs, you can't cancel your rent — but you can pause your streaming subscriptions and stop eating out. The difference between someone who panics in a financial emergency and someone who handles it is knowing exactly which dollars are flexible and which aren't.
keyPoints: Needs: expenses required for basic survival and functioning — housing, groceries, utilities, transportation to work, basic phone service, health insurance, minimum debt payments.
Wants: expenses that improve quality of life but aren't essential — streaming services, dining out, new sneakers, concert tickets, a premium phone plan, gym membership.
The gray zone: a phone is a need, but a $1,200 flagship phone is a want (a $200 phone covers the need). Food is a need, but a $45 restaurant meal is a want (groceries cover the need).
The 50/30/20 guideline: aim for 50% of net pay on needs, 30% on wants, and 20% on savings or debt payoff. It's a starting target, not a rigid rule.
In an emergency, wants are your release valve — they're the expenses you can cut immediately to free up cash for what matters.

examples.problem:
Categorize each monthly expense as a Want (W) or Need (N), then total each category.
Rent: $1,100 | Groceries: $340 | Car insurance: $145 | Netflix: $15.99 | Gym membership: $40 | Electricity: $95 | Dining out: $120 | Phone bill: $65 | New headphones: $79 | Gas for commute: $110
examples.solution:
Needs: Rent $1,100 + Groceries $340 + Car insurance $145 + Electricity $95 + Phone bill $65 + Gas $110 = $1,855.00.
Wants: Netflix $15.99 + Gym $40 + Dining out $120 + Headphones $79 = $254.99.

Total spending: $2,109.99. Needs = 87.9%. Wants = 12.1%.
Note: The phone bill could be debated — a basic plan is a need, but an unlimited premium plan has a want component. When in doubt, classify the minimum required cost as a need.

examples.problem: Marcus takes home $2,800/month after taxes (net pay). Using the 50/30/20 guideline, how much should he spend on needs, wants, and savings? His actual needs total $1,680. Is he within the guideline?
examples.solution:
50/30/20 targets:
Needs (50%): $2,800 × 0.50 = $1,400
Wants (30%): $2,800 × 0.30 = $840
Savings (20%): $2,800 × 0.20 = $560

His actual needs are $1,680, which is 60% of net pay ($1,680 ÷ $2,800 = 0.60). He's $280 over the 50% target.

Remaining after needs: $2,800 - $1,680 = $1,120. If he still saves $560 (20%), that leaves only $560 for wants — down from the $840 guideline. His budget still works, but his high needs squeeze his wants category.

examples.problem: In a financial emergency, which expenses can be cut immediately and which cannot? Monthly expenses: Rent $1,100, streaming services $48, groceries $320, dining out $180, car insurance $130, gym $50, electricity $95, haircut appointment $45.
examples.solution:
Can cut immediately (wants): Streaming $48 + Dining out $180 + Gym $50 + Haircut $45 = $323 freed up.
Cannot skip (needs): Rent $1,100 + Groceries $320 + Car insurance $130 + Electricity $95 = $1,645.

In one month, cutting all wants frees up $323. That's real money — enough to cover an unexpected car repair or medical bill. This is why knowing the difference matters: it's your financial emergency plan already built into your budget.

problems.question: Sort these monthly expenses into Needs and Wants, then find the total for each category. Rent: $925, Spotify: $11.99, Groceries: $285, Electricity: $78, Coffee shops: $55, Renter's insurance: $32, Bus pass: $65, New shoes (fashion): $89, Phone bill: $55, Water bill: $40.
hints: Ask: could I survive and get to work without this? If no, it's a need.
Rent, groceries, utilities (electricity, water), renter's insurance, transportation (bus pass), and a basic phone are needs.
Spotify, coffee shop trips, and fashion shoes are wants — enjoyable but not essential for survival.

problems.question: Devon takes home $2,200/month. Using the 50/30/20 rule, calculate his targets for needs, wants, and savings. His needs total $1,320. If he wants to hit his savings target, how much is left for wants?
hints: Calculate targets: 50% of $2,200 = $1,100 for needs, 30% = $660 for wants, 20% = $440 for savings.
His actual needs are $1,320 — subtract from income: $2,200 - $1,320 = $880 remaining.
If he saves $440 (the 20% target), wants get the remainder: $880 - $440.
problems.answer: Targets: Needs $1,100, Wants $660, Savings $440. Actual needs ($1,320) exceed the target by $220. After needs and savings ($1,320 + $440 = $1,760), only $440 is left for wants — $220 less than the guideline.

problems.question: Jasmine's monthly budget: Net income $3,100. Expenses — Rent $975, Groceries $360, Car payment $285, Car insurance $120, Gas $95, Electricity $85, Phone $60, Health insurance $110, Streaming services $32, Dining out $145, Clothing $75, Gym $45. (a) Categorize each as Need or Want. (b) What percentage of her income goes to needs? To wants? (c) Is she saving anything?
hints: Needs: rent, groceries, car payment, car insurance, gas, electricity, phone, health insurance. Wants: streaming, dining out, clothing, gym.
Subtract total spending from income to find what's left for savings.
problems.answer: Needs: $2,090 (67.4%). Wants: $297 (9.6%). Remaining for savings: $713 (23.0%). Jasmine's needs are high at 67.4%, but she keeps wants very low at 9.6%, giving her strong savings at 23%.

problems.question: Build a monthly budget with these constraints: Net income $2,500/month. Fixed needs: Rent $750 (with roommate), Groceries $250, Utilities $90, Phone $45, Bus pass $55, Renter's insurance $25. You want to save $100/month. How much is left for wants? Name two specific wants you could afford.
problems.answer: Needs: $750 + $250 + $90 + $45 + $55 + $25 = $1,215. After $100 savings: $2,500 - $1,215 - $100 = $1,185 available for wants. Examples: gym ($40), dining out ($150), streaming ($15), new clothes ($75), entertainment ($60) — with $1,185 there is healthy room. Needs are 48.6% of income, well within the 50% guideline.

problems.question: Angela takes home $2,600/month. Her needs total $1,950 (high-rent area). She spends $400/month on wants and saves $250/month. Her car needs a $1,200 repair and she has no emergency fund. Compare these three options using actual numbers: (A) Put it on a credit card at 24% APR and pay $100/month extra. (B) Cut wants to $0 and redirect all non-need money to a repair fund. (C) Cut wants to $200/month and build the repair fund more slowly. Which option do you recommend and why?
problems.answer: Option A: Credit card charges $1,200 × 24% ÷ 12 = $24/month interest. At $100/month payments, most of the early payments go to interest — total cost over $130 extra. Option B: Available per month = $2,600 - $1,950 = $650. All to repair fund = done in under 2 months, but zero wants or savings is harsh. Option C: Wants $200/month, repair fund gets $2,600 - $1,950 - $200 = $450/month. Done in under 3 months with no interest. Option C is the best balance — avoids $130+ in interest, takes about 3 months, and still allows $200/month for basic wants.

answerKeys.mrb-2: Job B pays $1,040 more per year ($36,400 vs $35,360)
answerKeys.mrb-4: They earn exactly the same: $38,480 per year each
answerKeys.mrb-5: Job 1 grosses $48,165 with overtime vs Job 2 at $48,000 — but overtime is not guaranteed, making Job 2 the safer choice
answerKeys.mrb-10: Net $1,463.24/paycheck, $2,926.48/month. After $950 rent: $1,976.48 left — yes, exceeds $1,000
answerKeys.mrb-15: Savings earns $120/year; credit card costs $60 in month one alone. Use savings to pay off the card.
answerKeys.mrb-17: $440 for wants after $1,320 needs and $440 savings
answerKeys.mrb-19: $1,185 available for wants after $1,215 needs and $100 savings
answerKeys.mrb-20: Option C — cut wants to $200/month, save $450/month, repair done in ~3 months, no interest
